commentBody:
I enjoyed this puzzle, and had trouble seeing my last entry, ALAS, NO. 

But as a pedantic nitpicker I found the clue "Unfortunately ..." less than fully appropriate for I FEAR. That is because I FEAR appears to be about something that is threatening but not yet confirmed, while "Unfortunately" seems to refer to something that is not at all iffy.
@Sam. In this part of the world a [seedy hotel] is a FLEApit
The Mini made me laugh at myself. I just couldn't figure out what GREEN had to do with a handshake. Once again I'm a victim of all those speed reading courses I took
I love ON KEY KONG so much. With a voice like that, maybe Mario should have been worried that Kong could steal the princess.

I kept trying to make Onkeykong a rebus and started with thinking that the rebus square was the KEY.
Nice flip on the head for American solvers trying to figure out how to spell Nunavut, though the crosses helped. Until the end I thought it was Nunavuk and had to figure out what square I had wrong. Nice solve with a de-lightful fun crunch
Sez…
Well done, Mr Keller.  Loved the puns, got some good smiles out of this puzzle.  I sez, you come back now, y’hear?

Is anyone going to pick a nit and observe that "Alien" is the first part of ALF's acronymic name, and this makes for a poor clue word? ("Puppet alien of TV")

Guess so. :)

Much fun, loved the pair of Jack Lalanne and Frank Oz!

Nunnery that doesn't allow male guests?
BAN OF BROTHERS

Underage drinker?
RUMMER BOY

Make use of some furniture to go down the river?
RAFTING TABLE

Nana comes into the room?
GRAN ENTRANCE

OK, I don't those those are all that funny. I didn't
HA ENOUGH
Clever and fun. Thank you.
41D: had FRANKO__ and dooked myself.

At the dinner table, if us kids ever said "I'M FULL," my mother would immediately jump in to correct our manners: "I'm satisfied." Under her breath she'd add: "You're not a balloon."
...............................................
Nice puzzle, Mr. Werfel! The themers made me smile. Thank you!

Wow what a DELIGHTful pitch perfect Tuesday. Loved the punny revealer, the themes and the fill. Loved the shout out to Frank Oz. Sorry we didn’t get a clue to the outstanding Phoebe Waller Bridge show for FLEABAG. Finally anyone else notice we had HIC two days in a row clued differently?
Perfect puzzle for a warm but rainy Monday.
Thank you, Mr. Werfel, for a DELIGHTful Tuesday romp.

Smooth sailing today. Nice puzzle with a cheeky pun. Nearly got tripped up by having Goop instead of GLUE and IMdone instead of IMFULL, but once those clicked, the rest fell into place.

Pleased I got NUNAVUT on my first pass and lucky that LALANNE was handled by the crosses.
Nice fun puzzle. Loved the theme entries. Happy Tuesday, y’all! Thanks, Justin!
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/09/29/tuesday-september-30-2025/#ny
Thank you Mr. Werfel for a delightful Tuesday puzzle! Way more fun for me than most  Tuesdays.

That was hard yet a lot of fun to work through many times before finally finishing it. 

Didn't quite understand the theme until reading the column,D'OH!

Can someone please explain H, to Homer?  ETA  Thanks in advance.

CORGI! TERI Garr! What's not to love in this nicely Toughened Up Tuesday?

I'm also amused picturing Yoda next to Jack LALANNE.
Mail order bries would have been DE-LIGHT-FUL.
I’M FULL o’ love for this DELIGHTful puzzle. Clever play on words for the theme. Looking forward to more from you, Justin.

Where is the punster Mike?? 

I hope he’s just on holiday and hasn’t been scared away by that meanie who asked him why he bothers with his almost daily puns… Come back Mike!! I miss you!
Only one trivia item. 🙂
No matter how many times this clue shows up… 2 down is NOT “ani.”
Oh no - Ono again!

I had EluDE instead of EVADE, so I had NUNuVUT instead of NUNAVUT (looked right to me), and LIE instead of VIE. Had everything filled in and couldn't figure out what was up, until I realized I wasn't entirely sure LIE could mean "struggle." Almost 5 min slower than my average Tuesday because of that error.

"I know that baseball officiator is no good - I have umpirical evidence!"

(He's on the diamond and it's rough.)

It's a Strip-Dees.
I'll show myself out.
“ONKEYKONG” was *chef’s kiss*
Probably my favorite Tuesday I can remember. Great puzzle!

Wasn't ALF a guy in a suit rather than a puppet? Almost everybody over here watched that show in the early 90s - it was one of the first popular American series to air in Poland, and back then we were all hungry to get a taste of "the West". It wasn't as successful as "Dynasty" though, which aired a year earlier. Whole families gathered before their Polish, East German and Soviet TVs to watch the camp and drama of that show, the first American soap opera broadcast in this country. The contrast between it and the sad, gray reality of Poland in 1990 - ravaged by the collapse of the old regime, and not yet made prosperous by democracy and market economy - was shocking. Unrealistic as "Dynasty" was, it gave us a taste of American culture. How different to our own it seemed!

My mother, a strong, independent woman who always gave men a run for their money in anything she did, was fascinated by the character of Alexis. I laughed at it a bit at the time but these days I can understand and respect why it was. Too bad I can't tell her that - she would appreciate it.

As for the puzzle... Meh. Another somewhat groany theme 🤷🏽. It was quite well constructed though, which I can recognize even if I didn't particularly like it. The fill was hard for me in places, and I almost looked up that very weird name in the SW corner, but in the end I managed to fill the grid on my own in a time only slightly longer than on a typical Tuesday (and 15% faster than yesterday).

I solved the Tuesday 9/30/2025 New York Times Daily Crossword in 12:24!

I started doing the crossword about a year ago, and today's was one of the most fun, truly a D-lite! 

And, on the mini, I learned reune is a word. :)
The theme made me happy, 67-across made me sad, and  revealer made me laugh…truly too intense of an emotional rollercoaster for a Tuesday morning

A hearing in which proposed charges are subject to the judgment of women who have dealt with two generations of toddlers:

GRAN JURY

Long time listener; first time caller.

This month was a doozy but it's the first that I've completed with all gold! Current and longest streak sitting at 45 after about 1.5 years of daily solving (and many more from the archive).

I feel the difficulty ramping recently, especially after Larry Snyder's contribution on Friday the 26th (oeuvre, and the southeast) and Alex Jiang's Saturday 13th entry (Takis/Elgin).

Here's to many months more!
Btw, SEZ is how one would transcribe the pronunciation of "says" in Polish 🤣
Reune?  Wtheck

I remember Jack LaLanne from my earliest days.  In summer, or on days I was sick I'd sometimes see him on morning TV.

I only later realized what an amazing physique he had, I think because I was used to seeing cartoon muscles and his were pretty close.

But then he'd do a few minutes of some simple calisthenics moves and the "workout" was done.  

Now I'm sure it did his fans a lot of good to get whatever exercise they could.  His was a noble occupation in my book.

But it was very clear that he didn't get that body by doing *that* workout regime.

Strange to hear his name after all these years.

Are the editors on vacation? AESOP and ONO are answers on consecutive days. No chance that this week's Monday and Tuesday could have been split further apart?

At least we have been spared OREO for two days at least.

Nan is a woman's name? That's what I call my grandma, but I dont know anyone with that name

And I agree with Paul V, two days in a row with almost identical clues and the same answer?

Cute theme though

While I will always take time to appreciate a good pun, I’ll also take time to bemoan a poor clue. I always hate to see “informally” at the end of a clue because it is NYT shorthand for ‘spelled any way the setter came up with to fit the grid’. But even with this in mind, “Declares, informally” still stands out as possibly my least favourite clue in all the time I’ve been doing crosswords.
Pfft. Someone oughta reune back in the spelling be where they belong.
Great puzzle! Smooth theme and some very nice cluing. On Key Kong! Nice
"On key Kong" was quite clever... :)
Is this thread also for the Mini? I saw people griping about 'reune', which wasnt in the main puzzle
Very fun theme and I will accept a few of the questionable fills to reach the goal of an enjoyable Tuesday puzzle.

Surprisingly, after my bulb moment,
I was delighted.

ELECTABLE PUZZLE!





Et tu, emu.
Very cute!

I breezed happily through this - until I reached the fitness guru, the puppeteer, the alien, Kelley, the tree (even CAN IT only distantly familiar) all in one corner and completely unknown!

I'm surprised that I've never heard of ALF, a great many US programmes percolate into the UK, even if I don't watch them. 

I got CATALOG from the crossers and slowly guessed my way to the rest and then looked up the answers.

Very, very clever. I didn't get the idea until I read the wordplay, not catching on to the lack of Ds. It all fits together so well.
“It's glue. Sticky stuff” - Elwood Blues
Somehow this puzzle felt harder than a Tuesday to me, but had just the right amount of aha moments. Loved it!

Delight indeed!  This had so much fun built in.

First, figuring out what the deal was with CROW CONTROL, not a common phrase.  That woke my brain up and when I cracked that riddle, it had a glee-burst.

Then, knowing a D would be missing, trying to guess the remaining theme answers with as few crosses as possible, fun in itself, and when they did fill in, not only getting a big aha, but wowing at the cleverness behind both clue and answer.  

Finally, trying to guess the revealer, getting nowhere.  After finally uncle-ing, uncovering it, and my jaw actually dropped with happy wonder at how funny and perfect it was.

What a theme!  Standing O!

Along the way, lovely answers – LATHE, OOZE, FLEABAG, HOW’D IT GO, NUNAVUT.  A PuzzPair© of I’M FULL and a backward ATE.  Not to mention the sweet wordplay clue [Left of a ship ... or what a ship may have left].

Justin, I came to the box feeling decent and left it feeling exuberant.  That is a gift.  Thank you!

Be still my heart...maybe a PB in the offing??? Quoting here from Firesign Theatre's "The Further Adventures of Nick Danger, Third Eye," a spoof on Old Time Radio: "CATHERWOOD: Yes, and at the last possible moment, he stopped on a dime! LT BRADSHAW: I see… CATHERWOOD: Unfortunately, the dime was in Mr. Rococo's pocket." https://youtu.be/RwG5c9IsgbA?si=dOuqtZhqV2J9_A7x Lots of quotable stuff; a classic!! This puzzle was right up my alley. Thanks, it was a delight, for sure! Hey Catherwood, how 'bout rolling up a couple of bombers and leaving them on the side table...
Way above my Tuesday average, and for that I'm grateful. Really well done puzzle with a chuckle; inducing theme.

Enjoyed this one quite a bit. The theme was very clever, with a delight-ful revealer. Felt more challenging than usual for a Tuesday, yet I solved it about two minutes faster than my average. Wonder if the corner with ACACIAS, LALANNE and FRANKOZ caused a lot of trouble? I don't think I'm familiar with the last of these three.

Very nice puzzle!
I'm glad other commenters enjoyed this one. I found it waaaaaay too easy for a Wednesday. This was Monday-lite. Boring. :(

I'm glad that Sam gives a shout-out to  Phoebe Waller-Bridges'  wonderful FLEABAG.  It's a great show.  I'm sorry that it only lasted two seasons, but I'm impressed by Ms. Waller-Bridges' ability to say "Enough!" and walk away, when she had a big hit.
I'm surprised, however, that Sam didn't know that it could also refer to a "Sleazy hotel".

However, I don't think that I ever knew why the show had that name.  I don't think it was ever explained in the series.  I had assumed that she was supposed to be a "sleazy, run-down" sort of a person. 
Today I learned that "FLEABAG" was actually Ms. Waller-Bridges' nickname when she was growing up; presumably a cute (but also cruel) mis-pronunciation of her given name "Phoebe".
Nice, breezy Tuesday puzzle with a clever theme.  Enjoyed it.
A speedy Tuesday fill, despite not knowing the tv personality.
Not the day for doing down only clues. Managed to get crow control and figure it must be a missing D theme from there but the south west scuppered me. Good puzzle though

I remember from early foreign language instruction not to say "Je suis plein(e)" to mean "I'M FULL."  We were taught that "Je suis plein(e)" meant "I'm pregnant."

I don't think I ever asked a native speaker whether this was true, but I remember with DELIGHT learning the Latin phrase "Ave Maria, gratia plena..." ["Hail Mary, full of grace"] and thinking, "Oh, she's FULL *that way*.

"I'm thinking about visiting Canadian Territories."
"Yukon if you want."

("Nunavut looks very interesting.")





(Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.)
(Mispronunciation is the sincerest form of punning.)
Good tricky puzzle. But no one in the history of ever has ever said DONE IT.

Hahaha
ON KEY KONG?
CROW CONTROL? 
GARBAGE UMP? 

This is hilarious. Absolutely loved this one. And the revealer is *chef's kiss*. I'm still giggling at the silliness of it all. What a fun theme.

And I can definitely relate to garbage ump. We used to have hockey season tickets that were close enough to the ice that the players could hear me. And I definitely let the refs know what I thought of their calls.
This was a fun one. Thanks, Justin!
"It's a delight" perfectly describes my thoughts about today's puzzle!  The fill was very pleasant and I adored the theme.  ON KEY KONG in particular made me giggle 😁

I wish to complain about all the TRIVIA in today's puzzle. But seriously, do folks really know what an ISBN is? I used to manage a college textbook store, so I had a working knowledge of them, but I expect that would be a bit niche for the rest of you. Even more niche; the prefix of the 13-digit number indicates the publisher, so 0-07 is McGraw-Hill, 0-380 is Harper-Collins, etc. I'll stop now. Lastly, in honor of 39D, here's some early Iron Maiden: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7LKvIZHkQw
As often happens, I solved the puzzle but totally blanked on the theme even after the puzzle was filled.
SEZ and GONEAPE are things absolutely no one sez.
Terrible Tuesday in my opinion.  Not a fan today unfortunately.
Fun puzzle until the SW corner had too many proper nouns that I didn’t know.

Just here to say, I think I got "Lalanne" so easily because I just finished Bonnie Garmus's "Lessons in Chemistry" and this gives me the opportunity to recommend it highly to anyone who has not yet read it. Most likely available at your local public library.

Oh - and I was delighted with the theme today. Made me chuckle :-)
Very easy! More like a Monday. Hello to that fifth Beatle, that Irish airline, that short struggle, and other perennials.
I thought the revealer was going to have something to do with the Kansas City Chiefs — no “D”. 😄
Loved the theme. Didn’t care for the rest of the puzzle.

Fun and quick Tuesday with lots of chuckles that others have referenced!

I realize I may be wandering into the lions den so maybe I should be commenting in the Boston Globe about this today! Nevertheless, I just need to give a shout out regarding the playoff revival of baseball's greatest rivalry playing the first of three (or two) wild card playoff games at Yankee Stadium tonight. No matter which team you root for (or even if you couldn't care less), this playoff match-up always promises to be exciting!
#GoRedSox⚾️
My GOONESS, that was fun!
NW corner starts with 4 proper nouns with a proper noun crossing them. we are starting the puzzle with a quadruple natick. not a great start.

I'm thrilled to be in Girl Scouts at last and eligible to VIE for merit badges.  The only badge I have earned so far, and imagine my surprise and delight when I was informed of this, is for 1006 pangrams in the Spelling Bee.  Had I only known I would have paid more attention to the other games. 

See you at the jamboree!

- Not to point out the obvious, but SEWER, FLEABAG and SEEDY in the same quadrant? Such must be the humble life of a NYT puzzle constructor. Do they not pay these folks well?

- I'm struggling to recall when I last said “ALASNO,” and the answer is never.

Real quick story of tuna INOIL; during ODS, the USPS offered free shipping to send care packages to those deployed to fight the Emir’s oil war. So, US grocery stores packaged up all their unsellable items and sent en masse to the desert. Tuna in water being more popular, ALL the tuna INOIL in America made its way to the Arabian Desert. And do , those cans explode reeeally well in pit fires! Still, they tasted better than chicken ALA king MREs (@Grant)
Okay I absolutely LOVED this one!  As a professional musician and gamer, ON KEY KONG may be my favorite entry in a NYT puzzle ever!
64A: Not [Year in Portugal]? Or [...Brasil]? SMH.
What a fantastic puzzle!

I loved it. Great theme, and seemed Tuesday-level to me. 
Still, I knew there would be some complaints. That’s one reason I only read a few of the most recent comments when I finish the daily xword. Also I have plenty of others things to do, and there’s enough negativity already in everyday life. 

I just finished reading a memoir by Bruce Springsteen, read by the man himself on my audiobook app. I loved it and recommend it highly.
Tedious.

Late to the party.  Solved early this morning but then had a water emergency but all is well now.  :)

Cole Porter said it best: 

"So please be sweet, my chickadee
And when I kiss you, just say to me
"It's delightful, it's delicious, it's delectable, it's delirious
It's dilemma, it's de-limit, it's deluxe, it's de-lovely"

Fun puzzle! While on vacation last month, I re-read (for the umpteenth time), *The Lathe of Heaven*, by Ursula K. LeGuin--one of my favorite of her novels, right after all the other favorite-of-her novels (Hi, @Pax Ahimsa Gethen!). May I recommend it. Or, if you prefer images to words, there is the 1980 made-for-(PBS)-TV movie version of it, starring Bruce Davidson and Margaret Avery. The production values, by today's standards are cheesy as all get out (turtles!), but it the ONLY adaptation of any of her works, which respects and follows the original. *** Here's a trio of On-key Primates: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=416o9b_pjQk&list=RD416o9b_pjQk&start_radio=1 *** I can never remember how to spell Jack Lalaññe's name.
Never knew Nunavut. Crosswords almost always expand my knowledge. Grazie.

I suppose I'm too botanically minded; I had "SEE(D)CATALOG" input for 47-A for a good chunk of time. I've never actually ordered from one before, but I've had lots of pleasure in flipping through and looking at all the beautiful pictures. Maybe one day!

Wow it's a long time since I've thought of Jack LaLanne! I remember my Nana exercising to his program in the early '60s, when I was really little. (Yes, i admit it, I pulled his show up on YouTube for nostalgia's sake!)
it's usually my favorite day of the week for these, but this tuesday was fantastic. thank you for the puzzle!
We're getting Donkey Kong themed answers left and right lately, I love it!

Busy day, late to the party. Anyway - a good workout for me, but enjoyed it when I tumbled to the trick and just had a great time figuring out each of the theme answers. And... a perhaps quite appropriate puzzle find today. A Thursday from November 10, 1994 by Alfio Micci. Must have been a lot of working the crosses in this one. Theme clues and answers. "M" : FIRSTOFTHEMONTH "O" : SECONDINCOMMAND "E" : BEETHOVENSTHIRD "Y" : THEFOURTHOFJULY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/10/1994&g=26&d=A ...

Man, SEZ with 2/3 of its letters crossing with proper nouns really padded my time :(

Had no idea what the names of 41 and 42 down were. I only remember Henson for Sesame Street. Though I figured the Z for Oz after looking up Lalanne. Originally had Say as my answer.

Kudos to this Monday: I thought laser toy or rubber mouse might be something computer related! As opposed to a CAT TOY.

As for Tuesday, I really enjoyed it. So funny. And @Sam thanks for explaining it’s a D light(minus a D).

Love the shout out to the brilliant Frank Oz, who also created and was the puppeteer for Yoda in the Empire Strikes Back.
I'm big time bummed that Mail Order Brie didn't make it into the puzzle. That's an astounding pun/play on words.
Excellent puzzle. Flowed right along.

I'm laughing at myself because I learned (after the FACT) that the Earth's gravity is nicknamed "one g" because it serves as the standard unit of measurement for g-force; I was reading it as "o-neg" like I was trying to force the "o" to be "0"(zero) + negativity. Twisted that up real good 🤪

Loved the flow of of this puzzle-- and all the humor found therein.
SEZ? Lalanne and Frankoz? Seriously?
Such a fun puzzle!  Loved the lighthearted and clever wordplay throughout.  I found the cluing bright and fresh, as well.  Fun way to start the week.  I look forward to more from this constructor.
ONKEYKONG definitely deserved its place in the center of the grid haha love it
Hey yoko and Aesop again
Heheheh ano instead of año (yes I’m 12)

@Dan “I fear” can be a synonym for “unfortunately” but its use is somewhat antiquated. For example, I can imagine a Jane Austen character saying “You may wish to sit down, as I fear I have some bad news to impart.” 
To digress a bit: I once heard that Apple Store employees were told to never say “unfortunately “, but instead say “as it turns out”. 
“As it turns out, your phone is completely hooped beyond repair “ sounds so much better than “Unfortunately…” 
I have no idea if this is true or not.

Mariana — yeah, I've heard "I fear" used that way myself. But it doesn't strike me as appropriate (though "regret" in lieu of "fear" would be peachy-keen).

(PS — are you related to the famous trench of the same name?)
@Dan I fear I am not.

@Mariana

Now that's a response with sense and sensibility.

@Mariana
One notable recent use of the phrase is in the song "Into the Unknown" from Frozen 2:

You're not a voice, you're just a ringing in my ear
And if I heard you (which I don't) I'm spoken for, I fear
@Dan as a Brit it sounds pretty natural as a synonym for “unfortunately” to me. Similarly “I’m afraid that…” is still largely used as an apologetic lead in, like “sorry to say…”

@Dan
I was delighted to see ALASNO, a phrase I use often -- for which habit I was mercilessly mocked by the Grade XI-ers I taught last year. Apparently, I "talk like a book." I told them thank you, which completely scuppered 'em.
@Dan Literally you are correct. But LITERATURE-wise, "I fear..." is used quite a bit to express dismay.
@Patrick J. I’m having to remember the term bum bag as that form of satchel is coming back in style

@Patrick J. When I was just a wee M. Biggen I stayed at a flea pit in Sydney for two nights and had a fabulous time. A few years later I returned to stay at a snooty B&B and an upscale hotel near the opera house, both so dreadfully dull and outrageously expensive that I found myself longing for the flea pit (or perhaps it was my youth…)

@Patrick J.
FLEABAG originally referred to the mattresses which came not only with ticking but also with tick🕷s.
            🕷
🕷     🕷🕷

                             🕷

@SBK

Thanks, that makes much more sense.  I didn't think it sounded right to say merely "fleabag" instead of the proper phrase "fleabag motel", as in a motel containing fleabags...

@K Barrett
Same.

@K Barrett
Me too!  GREEt was a good answer, right?  And tEST going down is a valid word -- but the egg would be in a testtube, and there was no  tube in sight.  I figured out NEST, and then went back to look at the Across clue again.  Oh -- that's where the extra T went!

@Bryan
And yer problem is?
@SBK probably that nobody under the sun says sez

@Sonja

I think everyone sez says.

@Francis

Say-ez you.

:)

(You don't say!)
@B not me 😀

@B

On a related note, thanks to scripts on the Internet I can finally confirm one of several things that I as a mere young wee nitpicker first hated about the movie E.T.

There's never an explanation of the term "E.T." in the movie!  Elliott just flat out makes it up out of nowhere and tells him that's his new name.  (There's one mention of the word extraterrestrial in a completely separate section - not in the original script either - and zero explanation that ET is meant to stand for that word.  The first time "ET" is used is when Elliot whips it out to name him.)

The only reason audiences didn't notice/care was the exhaustive marketing campaign whose tagline was  literally "E.T., the Extraterrestrial".  Yet there is NO basis for this in the actual movie!  It was incredibly grating.  And that's the least of my problems with that movie.  (Its antiscience worldview drove me up the wall.)  ALF was a masterpiece by comparison.

@B

Amen and Hallelujah!

I didn't like that movie much myself.  I was in a strange period of my life at that time,  but I recall it being weirdly unsettling.  I was no longer a kid at that point, and the kids acted so differently than I think I would have.

I really lost it with the whole cheesy fake-out at the end.  I don't know what the statue of limitations is for spoilers, but I'm not taking any chances, by just blurting out that ET doesn't really die in the end, even though the movie went to great lengths to convince us was he was dead.

@Francis and @Andrzej ,

It's good to have curmudgeonly company.

Yeah, the alien as obvious Christ figure didn't help either, though that's an insanely common movie trope.

All this said, the warbling yet ear wormy Neil Diamond tune "Turn On Your Heartlight" may be an even worse outcome.

Sigh, there was really nothing positive about that movie.

@B and others who hated ET.  You've made me stop regretting how little I saw of it. We saw it at a drive-in with our toddler, having fallen for the advice that this was a great way to avoid needing a babysitter.  "The kid will fall asleep." So wrong! She didn't but also couldn't figure out the movie thing. We didn't have much money back then but should have learned better. For maybe her first 6 months she would fall asleep in a real movie theater, but then that ended just when it was a movie with subtitles that I missed because I had to remove to the lobby...hence being suckered into trying a drive-in.

@john ezra

Excellent! :-D
@john ezra They were own right good.
@john ezra these are all goo!
@john ezra We're investing in a mutual fun!

One more that my wife just came up with:

Amico?
PAL IN ROME

@sotto voce O MY! I've never heard "I'm full" as anything but a big compliment. It always meant that the person ate quite a lot of whatever was served. Not dainty enough for you? Excuuuuse me, but I'm full.
@B The name of the poster.
@sotto voce whereas my mother had an inflated opinion of her children
@sotto voce. A loud burp was indicative at ours. I later learnt to follow up with “Must be a barge coming through”, or “That tasted better going down then coming back up”. Thank you Mr. Watterson!

@sotto voce

If you had said "I'M done" she might have tried to stick a fork in you.

@SP
Nope but I didn't read that clue, as I got it on the crosses. I often find myself saying, "That was in there?!?" when someone here mentions a solve that I missed in my trundle to the solution.

@Eric Hougland

Great song choice! :-)

@_chs_
ETA is the Greekk letter H.
@_chs_ The H-shaped letter in the Greek alphabet is named eta. And this Homer is Greek.

@Francis

To be clear the capital eta is represented by what looks like the letter H and apparently started with our H sound in very early Greek but even in classical Greek and up to this day it dropped that and was completely a vowel sound. If they wanted to represent our H sound they would use a rough breathing symbol before the vowel which looked like an apostrophe. So Homer was spelled Ὅμηρος and doesn’t use an eta at all as the first letter—that’s not a nit, eta was still H to Homer, the clue is accurate, but many people get confused by it thinking the letters are equivalent.

@SP

One of my deepest abysses of ignorance is Greek. 

I simply do not know anything about it, other than the letters (some of them) because of the sciences.

I went to a big grad school from a tiny, local undergrad school.  I was terrified that I'd not make it.  

So I resolved to the be the best note-taker ever.  The first day of Advanced Physical Chemistry, the professor used the lower case greek letter, xi, ξ.  And it came up over and over and over in equation after equation and my notes were a disaster.

So I spent the next couple days learning how to write that letter.  Hundreds of times.  Maybe thousands.  I got absolutely fluid.  In fact, I think I can do it to this day.

So I go into the lecture prepared, and literally the first thing the professor did was to define a new constant that subsumed the xi variable.

And I've never needed it since.

I'm entering that into the "Weird Flex, but ok" contest.
Thank you all

I remember my brother and I watching Jack LaLanne on Sataurday mornings when we were young.  

I don't know why we watched, as neither of us was even remotely interested in physical fitness.  I think it must have been on at a time when there were no cartoons to watch.  We ony had three TV statiions to choose from, and sometimes we had to settle for the least objectiional choice.

Good memories.

@Doug

Only three stations, eh? When I was a kid - in the 80s! - Poland had two, of which one only had a few hours a day of programs 🤣

@Francis

Even stranger, about an hour before I did this puzzle, a post about Jack LaLanne appeared in my Facebook feed. As is common on that site that keeps me reading political posts for hours, it was posted by someone I never heard of. It's as if FB knew I was going to do today's puzzle. Creepy.
@Andrzej In Telluride Colorado, we had one, CBS, and it didn't come in to well.

@Francis
I thought, "Wow, that's going WAY back!"  We didn't have a TV until the late 50's, so I must have seen it on the neighbors' television.  Pickings were slim in those days of three-channel programming.

@Francis I'm currently reading Alison Bechdel's _The Secret to Superhuman Strength_ and she mentions watching Jack LaLanne in the 60s, so it was a gimme for me as well! (I know I saw it a couple times on television, but it may have been reruns?)

@Francis
I vaguely recall that he wore one-piece jumpsuits everywhere. Didn't he do stunts on "Wide World of Sports," like pulling trains? And he invented fitness bands and protein bars.

@Francis I also have fond memories.  I remember occasionally going to a Jack Lalanne inspired fitness class with my mother in the sixties when my nana couldn't babysit.  I think he did a lot of people a lot of good.  My mom had never exercised in her life, and it was a springboard into sports for her.  She's eighty now and still fit.

@Kevin

Telluride is so gorgeous, a TV seems unnecessary.

@Tricia J

Yes, I believe he did.

I also remember a day when he started with a letter from a kid saying his father could do "a flag", which meant he could hold himself in a horizontal "flag" position using using his arms to hold onto a vertical pole.

He demonstrated and said the kid's father must have really been strong to be able to do that.

He was an interesting personality.

@Brian

Betty is short for Elizabeth.
Some older books refer to Anne Boleyn as "NAN Bullen"...which goes back pretty far...
And as our colleague above points out, NANCY might be called NAN.
In the US, NANA is a common "grandmother name"--Grandma and Granny being somewhat out of style.

@Throckmorton It's a good rule of thumb when solving crosswords, not to mention in other aspects of life, not to conflate one's own experiences with the entirety of what exists out there. Here's a page with a list of people named NAN, most of which are women: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nan

@Grant I would also suggest that the clue isn't really accurate. Library volumes are generally IDed by Dewey Decimal or Library of Congress call numbers, not ISBNs (I worked in publishing for years so I too am familiar with ISBNs. In the old days regular people used ISBNs to order books, but now I suspect most folks just use Amazon).

Dave,

I think the editors used "library volume" in the clue instead of just plain "book" because the B of ISBN is "book."

Grant,

I secured the ISBNs for a couple of books issued by the magazine publishing company I worked for 50 years ago.
@Grant I have no professional library or bookstore experience and knew the answer instantly. I do read a lot, which is probably a factor.

@Dave Munger
More inside baseball; I was in the biz when they changed from ISBN-10 to ISBN-13, as there was concern that they would run out of 10-digit numbers, in a Y2K-type crisis. (There's an algorithm that converts one to the other.) We had kids coming into my store to copy the ISBN on the shelf tags so they could order the correct version online. It wasn't long afterwards that I went to work at Amazon...the writing was on the wall.
@Grant I knew what it was asking for but I can never remember the sequence of the first 3 letters, so I relied on the crosses to fill it in
@Barry Ancona Volume = book; all indexed / IDed by call numbers, not ISBNS in libraries.

@Grant - I go by memory. 

"Hmmm, where is that treatise on subtidal clams? Let's see -- must be on the bookcase on marine biology. The first such bookcase out of three. I think it was rather large, so probably on the bottom shelf. It had a red binding.... 

Hmmm... not there. Maybe I stuck on the bookshelf for oversized items. 

Oh there it is! Not as large as I remembered, and in a blue binding, not red!"

@Grant - My ex was a neat freak and it annoyed her to no end that I had so many books and that they appeared, to her eye, to be arranged willy-nilly. 

She decided to arrange all my books by size and color. 

It was very attractive and orderly, but I couldn't find a darned thing. 

I have downsized drastically after retirement -- my "library" maxed out at about 4,000 volumes several years ago and I think it's down to about 1,000 now. This is what happens when you move into a cabin in the woods. 

On the positive side, I now have no qualms about buying new books. 

I would imagine the concept of a library of this size would cause heads to 'splode among the young'uns.
